title: IDOR in Report CSV export discloses the IDs of Custom Field Attributes of Programs

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
Specifying a report ID of another team when requesting a CSV export leaks the ID of the Custom Field Attribute in the CSV header.

**Request**
```
POST /reports/export HTTP/1.1
Host: localhost:8080
...

----------868143055
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="report_ids[]"

17
----------868143055
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="report_ids[]"

118
...
```

**Response**
```
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
...

id,title,severity_rating,severity_score,state,substate,weakness,reported_at,first_response_at,triaged_at,closed_at,awarded_at,assigned,reporter,bounty,bonus,public,reference,reference_url,structured_scope,original_report_id,custom_field_1,custom_field_2,custom_field_3,custom_field_4,custom_field_5,custom_field_6
17,Brute force in login form,low,,open,new,HTTP Response Splitting,2019-02-07 02:49:29 UTC,2019-02-07 02:49:30 UTC,,2019-02-07 02:49:30 UTC,,,sandra,,,no,,,https://profile-photos.hackerone-user-content.com/,,"'[a](https://google.com)',a",d,,,,
```

In the above request, report ID 17 belongs to the current user's program, which is why Custom Field 1, 2, 3, 4, and 6 are included. Custom Field 5 belongs to the Program for Report ID 118. The current user does not have access to this program, but the Custom Field is still included in the header. The program also doesn't have the feature toggle enabled, which means that this is currently exploitable on hackerone.com.

## Impact

This can be used to get an exact count of Program Reports for Programs that have at least one attribute. This is currently exploitable on hackerone.com. However, as Custom Fields has not been released to other programs besides our own, there is currently no sensitive data being exposed.
vulnerability_information_html:
Specifying a report ID of another team when requesting a CSV export leaks the ID of the Custom Field Attribute in the CSV header.

Request

POST /reports/export HTTP/1.1
Host: localhost:8080
...

----------868143055
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="report_ids[]"

17
----------868143055
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="report_ids[]"

118
...

Response

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
...

id,title,severity_rating,severity_score,state,substate,weakness,reported_at,first_response_at,triaged_at,closed_at,awarded_at,assigned,reporter,bounty,bonus,public,reference,reference_url,structured_scope,original_report_id,custom_field_1,custom_field_2,custom_field_3,custom_field_4,custom_field_5,custom_field_6
17,Brute force in login form,low,,open,new,HTTP Response Splitting,2019-02-07 02:49:29 UTC,2019-02-07 02:49:30 UTC,,2019-02-07 02:49:30 UTC,,,sandra,,,no,,,https://profile-photos.hackerone-user-content.com/,,"'[a](https://google.com)',a",d,,,,

In the above request, report ID 17 belongs to the current user's program, which is why Custom Field 1, 2, 3, 4, and 6 are included. Custom Field 5 belongs to the Program for Report ID 118. The current user does not have access to this program, but the Custom Field is still included in the header. The program also doesn't have the feature toggle enabled, which means that this is currently exploitable on hackerone.com.

Impact

This can be used to get an exact count of Program Reports for Programs that have at least one attribute. This is currently exploitable on hackerone.com. However, as Custom Fields has not been released to other programs besides our own, there is currently no sensitive data being exposed.

activities.message:
A fix has been deployed. Before the patch was deployed, the controller action would dispatch the request to a class that handles authorization, input validation, and business logic. This class would receive an array of report IDs. The authorization check would pass when the user was signed in. The class would dispatch the call to a separate class to collect all the information for the CSV export based on the given report IDs. This class would make an intersection between the given report IDs and the reports the signed in user has access to. Up until the introduction of Custom Fields, this was not a problem because the CSV structure was the same for every program. Passing report IDs that a user wouldn't have access to would result in an empty CSV being returned.

With the introduction of Custom Fields, additional headers would be added based on the report IDs. We incorrectly assumed that the class had already made sure that the report IDs were authorized, which wasn't the case. This caused a minor security vulnerability where the IDs of Custom Field Attributes were leaked. The fix added a proper authorization check in the class that the request is initially dispatched to. The diff (without additional specs) can be seen below. Requesting a report to be exported that the user doesn't have access to will now result in an error instead of an empty CSV.

```diff
--- a/app/backend/interactors/reports/export.rb
+++ b/app/backend/interactors/reports/export.rb
@@ -10,7 +10,12 @@ module Interactors
       private

       def authorized?
-        authenticated?
+        return false unless current_user
+
+        team_ids = Team.joins(:reports).where(reports: { id: report_ids }).ids
+        membership_ids = current_user.team_ids
+
+        (team_ids - membership_ids).empty?
       end

       def execute
```
activities.markdown_message:
A fix has been deployed. Before the patch was deployed, the controller action would dispatch the request to a class that handles authorization, input validation, and business logic. This class would receive an array of report IDs. The authorization check would pass when the user was signed in. The class would dispatch the call to a separate class to collect all the information for the CSV export based on the given report IDs. This class would make an intersection between the given report IDs and the reports the signed in user has access to. Up until the introduction of Custom Fields, this was not a problem because the CSV structure was the same for every program. Passing report IDs that a user wouldn't have access to would result in an empty CSV being returned.

With the introduction of Custom Fields, additional headers would be added based on the report IDs. We incorrectly assumed that the class had already made sure that the report IDs were authorized, which wasn't the case. This caused a minor security vulnerability where the IDs of Custom Field Attributes were leaked. The fix added a proper authorization check in the class that the request is initially dispatched to. The diff (without additional specs) can be seen below. Requesting a report to be exported that the user doesn't have access to will now result in an error instead of an empty CSV.

--- a/app/backend/interactors/reports/export.rb
+++ b/app/backend/interactors/reports/export.rb
@@ -10,7 +10,12 @@ module Interactors
       private

       def authorized?
-        authenticated?
+        return false unless current_user
+
+        team_ids = Team.joins(:reports).where(reports: { id: report_ids }).ids
+        membership_ids = current_user.team_ids
+
+        (team_ids - membership_ids).empty?
       end

       def execute

activities.message: This was discovered during an internal security review.
activities.markdown_message: This was discovered during an internal security review.

activities.message: @jobert I'm unfamiliar with the client facing app, where would I find this through the GUI?
activities.markdown_message: @jobert I'm unfamiliar with the client facing app, where would I find this through the GUI?

activities.message:
The functionality is invoked from 2 places. The first is within the inbox, after selecting several reports you'll see a link that shows "Download as CSV":
{F449407}

This is the one that accepts an array of reports ids, probably most susceptible to the attack above. The second place is in the team settings page https://hackerone.com/<handle>/export_reports.

Let us know if you have any other questions!
activities.markdown_message:
The functionality is invoked from 2 places. The first is within the inbox, after selecting several reports you'll see a link that shows "Download as CSV":

This is the one that accepts an array of reports ids, probably most susceptible to the attack above. The second place is in the team settings page https://hackerone.com/<handle>/export_reports.

Let us know if you have any other questions!

activities.message: I don't see download csv option when i follow ' inbox, after selecting several reports you'll see a link that shows "Download as CSV":'. I only see 'Clear Selection'. PFA
activities.markdown_message: I don't see download csv option when i follow ' inbox, after selecting several reports you'll see a link that shows "Download as CSV":'. I only see 'Clear Selection'. PFA

activities.message: I believe you need to be logged in as a client/customer, not a researcher.
activities.markdown_message: I believe you need to be logged in as a client/customer, not a researcher.

I'm not sure if the feature Download as CSV is available for BASIC or STAGING team.
Here's a screenshot how it looks on my side.

activities.message: Good questions, this feature is available in the inbox as a team member, so you may need to create a sandbox program, easy to setup at https://hackerone.com/teams/new
activities.markdown_message: Good questions, this feature is available in the inbox as a team member, so you may need to create a sandbox program, easy to setup at https://hackerone.com/teams/new

activities.message:
Hi @bencode 
I guess my comment wasn't clear. I created a sandbox program and that screenshot is from that program (me being admin).
I don't have that **Download as CSV** option.

activities.message:
Hi @faisalahmed and @npbhatter17 - we'd like to close the loop on this one! To clarify: if you want the "Download as CSV" option to appear, you have to select the program from the top left selector in the Inbox (as shown below) and then select a number of reports. The option will show up on the right. Let us know if you have any further questions. Thanks!

{F463127}
activities.markdown_message: Hi @faisalahmed and @npbhatter17 - we'd like to close the loop on this one! To clarify: if you want the "Download as CSV" option to appear, you have to select the program from the top left selector in the Inbox (as shown below) and then select a number of reports. The option will show up on the right. Let us know if you have any further questions. Thanks!
